nexttext: where $P=\frac{N(N-1)}{2}$ is the number of pairs, $D$ is a parabolic cylinder function \cite{gradshteyn} which depends on the absolute separation between the particles $r_{ij}=|x_j-x_i|$ and the parameters $\beta_{ij}$ and $\mu_{ij}$. $C_r$ is a normalization constant. This form of the relative wave function has first been proposed for equal interactions in \cite{brouzos} and is based on the exact solution for the case of two bosons in a harmonic trap \cite{busch}. It has been shown to produce good agreement with numerical methods in the few-particle cases of equal interaction \cite{brouzos}. For the case of different interactions a similar approach has been proposed in \cite{39D,barfk} for the homogeneous case. Here we combine these two approaches to treat the general case of different interactions in a trap. By using the boundary condition for the delta function potential between a pair of particles, $2\beta_{ij} D'(0|\beta_{ij},\mu_{ij})=g_{ij}D(0|\beta_{ij},\mu_{ij})$, we obtain the following relation for $\mu_{ij}$ and $g_{ij}$:

where $\Gamma$ are Gamma functions and $\mu_{ij}$ varies between 0 and 1 as $g_{ij}$ grows from 0 to $\infty$. By choosing all $\beta_{ij}=\sqrt{2/N}$ and considering all interactions equal ($g_{ij}=g$ for any pair) the total wave function reproduces the known analytical ground state results in the non-interacting

|x_{j}-x_{i}|" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>i</mi><mi>N</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mfrac><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo><</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><mi>P</mi></munderover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: By symmetry considerations, it is enough to determine the coefficients at these two regions. For a given choice of $\rho=\rho_0$, at the contact points between the particles the delta potential introduces a derivative discontinuity of the kind

prevtext: By symmetry considerations, it is enough to determine the coefficients at these two regions. For a given choice of $\rho=\rho_0$, at the contact points between the particles the delta potential introduces a derivative discontinuity of the kind

nexttext:
and $G_{IM}\equiv \sqrt{2}g_{IM}\rho_0$. This last parameter becomes independent of $\rho_0$ as $g_{IM}\rightarrow \infty$. By exploiting these conditions, the continuity of the wave function at the six contact points, and choosing $g_{MM}=0$, we arrive finally at the wave function for the two lowest states in the case of infinitely repulsive impurity and two non-interacting bosons:
\begin{eqnarray}
\psi(z,\rho,\phi)&=Ce^{-z^2/2}\rho^{3/2}e^{-\rho^2/2}\times \nonumber\\&\left\{
\begin{array}{lr}
\sin(\frac{3}{2}(\phi+\frac{\pi}{6})) &: \phi \in \textbf{III}\\
0 &: \phi \in \textbf{II}\\
\mp\sin(\frac{3}{2}(\phi-\frac{\pi}{6})) &: \phi \in \textbf{I}\\
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray} 
(-) for the ground state with even parity, and (+) for the 1st excited state with odd parity. Notice that the wave function is symmetric in the regions \textbf{I} and \textbf{IV}, \textbf{II} and \textbf{V} and finally \textbf{III} and \textbf{VI}. From here one can easily calculate all the results discussed in the main text.
